Additional predators include the Long-tailed Weasel (Mustela frenata), Red-tailed Hawks (Buteo jamaicensis), and rattlesnakes (Crotalus spp.) (Cervantes-Reza 1981, Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).
threats:
The Volcano Rabbit is threatened by habitat destruction, caused by livestock grazing, agriculture and property development encroachment, logging, harvest of the “zacaton” grasses, and fires (98% of which are started by humans attempting to encourage new pasture growth) (Fa and Bell 1990). Its range is within 45 minutes of one of the world’s largest cities (Mexico City) and urban expansion has resulted in habitat loss (Fa and Bell 1990), which is ongoing. Today, suitable habitat for the Volcano Rabbit in the Ajusco-Chichinautzin Mountains covers 7,544 ha, equivalent to only 13.68% of the landscape, including 957 patches: 293 have a minimum area of 0.25 ha and only two are larger than 1,000 ha (Uriostegui-Velarde et al 2018). Though hunting is illegal, it continues because of lack of local knowledge of its protected status, and lack of enforcement (Cervantes et al. 1990, Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

Reduction of habitat quality associated to the presence of pasture lands, crops, and roads may have a stressful effect on the rabbits, as mean cortisol metabolites levels measured in its faeces were more than two times higher in highly degraded habitat compared to the low degraded habitat (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2014).

Climate change is likely to have severe consequences for this species. Anderson et al. (2009) predicted that the lower elevation range limit of the Volcano Rabbit may shift upslope by approximately 700 m during the next 100 years, which will reduce the area occupied by the species, as the mountain peaks currently lack suitable habitat.
population:
An early estimate of the population of the Volcano Rabbit was 7,085 rabbits; 1,811 individuals in Pelado, 1,816 in Tlaloc, 3,458 in Izta-Popo and approximately 3,056 for the surrounding areas (Portales et al. 1997). Due to a variety of continuous and ongoing threats, its population is likely to be lower at the present time.

Population densities estimated by line transects are variable between regions. Studies conducted on the Pelado Volcano indicated that densities ranged from 0.11 to 1.2 rabbits/ha according to habitat characteristics (Velázquez 1994); in the Biological Corredor Chichinautzin the density was estimated to be 4.2 individuals/ha (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2016). Other studies have shown the relative abundance based on fecal pellet counts is also highly variable throughout its distribution, ranging from 0.1 to 3.1 latrines/m² in habitat on the Volcano Pelado (Velázquez 1994, Velázquez and Heil 1996), and 0.02 to 0.12 latrines/m² in Sierra Chichinautzin (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2015).

The only study that has monitored trends in population was conducted in a core population in the Sierra Chichinautzin based on density estimates using pellet counts (Guerrero et al. in press). This study indicated that Volcano Rabbit density declined from 4.2 individuals/ha in 2011 to <1 individual/ha in 2017.

Initial studies indicated that the Volcano Rabbit occupied fragmented habitat, and that there were 16 discrete occupied habitat fragments (Portales et al. 1997); the current number of isolated habitat polygons is 19. More recent evaluation of the degree of fragmentation within occupied habitat polygons was able to discern significantly more fine-scale Volcano Rabbit habitat fragmentation (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018). At the landscape level 957 patches of available habitat covering 75.44 km² were identified along the Ajusco-Chichinautzin Mountain Range (thus encompassing Tlaloc Volcano, Pelado Volcano, and Coajomulco forests), most (N = 293) of which had a minimum area of 2,500 m². Only two patches were larger than 1,000 ha. 144 plots were sampled intensively, and of these 50 contained no evidence of Volcano Rabbit presence (no latrines were located); on only five plots were there more than 100 latrines, indicating the presence of a highly viable population (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018).
range:
The Volcano Rabbit is endemic to Mexico, restricted to the Transverse Neovolcanic Belt, mainly in discontinuous patches on four volcanoes (Popocatepetl, Iztaccihuatl, El Pelado, Tlaloc) and the Sierra Chichinautzin (Rizo-Aguilar et al.2016, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). An initial estimate of area of occupancy (AOO) was approximately 386 km² based on occupancy on the four volcanoes (Velazquez 1994), although this area has subsequently been reduced to 335 km². Recent observations, based on latrine records and sightings in the Biological Corridor Chichinautzin, have added 109 km² to this distribution (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2016). A recent survey in the Parque Ecoturístico Piedra Canteada, along the Tlaxcala/Puebla border, north of Iztaccihuatl, yielded a recent siting of Volcano Rabbits, but the extent is unknown (Ramírez-Albores et al.2014). As a result of the over 15 years continuous volcanic activity of the Popocatepetl Volcano, the distribution range has shifted and expanded, locally. Currently, the discontinuous EOO is 2,469 km². The whole range, however, is becoming increasingly fragmented as a result of human-induced and natural causes (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018, Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

The Volcano Rabbit occurs between 2,900 m and 4,250 m in elevation (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2015, 2016), but its highest density is found between 3,150 m and 3,400 m (Velazquez 1994).
useTrade: In some areas, this species is hunted for food.
conservationActions:
The Volcano Rabbit is listed under Appendix I of CITES (1973), although the species has never been involved in international trade and this listing is apparently an historical artifact. Hunting is illegal according to Mexican law, but poorly enforced (Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). It is listed as endangered in the Mexican Official Norm NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 (SEMARNAT 2010). It occurs within the protected areas Izta-Popo and Zoquiapan National Parks, but hunting, grazing, and grass burning persist within the park boundaries (Cervantes et al. 1990, Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez et al. 1993, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

Captive breeding programs have been established with some success, but infant mortality in captivity is very high (Fa and Bell 1990).

It is recommended that conservation measures focus on habitat management, particularly the control of burning and overgrazing of the bunchgrass “zacaton” habitat, and enforcement of the existing laws prohibiting hunting and trade of the Volcano Rabbit (Fa and Bell 1990, Hunter and Cresswell 2015, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). Management of the protected areas should be improved and education plans at local, national, and international levels should be implemented (Fa and Bell 1990, Portales et al. 1997, Hunter and Cresswell 2015, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). Captive colonies, especially those in the zoos of Mexico City should be used to educate the public about the protected status of the Volcano Rabbit (Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

rationale: Annamite Striped Rabbit is categorised as Endangered based on the rates of decline inferred over the 10-year period (a period exceeding that of three generations) to 2018 (past), the 10-year period from 2018 (future), and any 10-year period including 2018 within it (ongoing). Illegal hunting pressure is extremely high throughout the species' known global range. This poaching is primarily accomplished with wire snares; is almost ubiquitous across the Annamite forests, even in protected areas; and has resulted in precipitous declines of almost all ground-dwelling mammal and bird species similar in size to or larger than this rabbit. There is no reason to believe that populations of Annamite Striped Rabbit have not suffered declines comparable to those of other similarly sized mammals in the Annamites. There are indications that it is more sensitive to hunting than are some comparably sized ground-dwelling mammal species. Best-case scenarios, incorporating insight for similar-size ground-dwelling mammal species, suggest that the global population of Annamite Striped Rabbit has declined by more than 50% over the 10-year time period to 2018. Camera-trapping indicates that although the species is still present in detectable numbers across much of its known range, it is nevertheless uncommon in areas that have undergone, or are currently experiencing, intense poaching pressure, compared with what can be ascertained of populations before the onset of intensive snaring. Although it is evidently more abundant than are some of the larger Annamite endemic mammal species such as Saola Pseudoryx nghetinhensis and Large-antlered Muntjac Muntiacus vuquangensis, indicating (even allowing for different pre-exploitation densities) that its populations have not been as negatively affected by snaring as have the ungulates, these latter species’ populations have been assessed as having recent rates of decline almost certainly over 90%. Moreover, Annamite Striped Rabbit appears effectively to be restricted to wet evergreen forest: this means that the vast majority of its range is in Viet Nam, where snaring pressure has been recently, and remains, remarkably high; therefore, a higher percentage of its global population  has been exposed to these high levels of snaring than for Annamite endemic or near-endemic mammals with more flexible habitat requirements and that extend further westward into Lao PDR, such as Owston’s Civet Chrotogale owstoni. As of 2018, it has been over 20 years (two assessment windows of time for this species under Category A) since intensive snaring started to sweep through the Annamite mountains, and it is likely that over 95% of Annamite Striped Rabbit’s occupied range has at some point experienced intensive snaring (i.e., over 100 snares per km², equating to 3,000 snare-nights per km², per month). Comparing the relative levels of decline at first wave of industrial snaring with those subsequently, and looking at geographic patterns of expansion of this snaring between the mid 1990s and 2018, the consensus assessment of surveyors and wildlife researchers active in the species's range is that in the 10 years to 2018 it declined by 50-65%. It is extremely unlikely that hunting pressure will decrease to a point that would allow widespread population recovery in the near future; continuing population declines extending into the next 10 years (from 2018) of comparable magnitude are suspected to be likely.
habitat:
To date, no studies have focused on the ecology of Annamite Striped Rabbit. Nonetheless, some general natural history traits can be surmised from camera-trap records and villager information. It is clear that it occurs predominantly in wet evergreen forest, that which has little to no dry season (probably no month with rainfall below 40 mm; Rundel 1999). Most records come from low- to mid-elevation broadleaf forest. As an example of typical Annamite Striped Rabbit occurrence patterns, camera-trapping in three protected areas in Viet Nam, Phong Dien Nature Reserve (= NR), Khe Nuoc Trong proposed NR and Bac Huong Hoa NR, detected Annamite Striped Rabbit in broadleaf wet evergreen forest from 50 to 1,183 m asl (Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2017). There is one record in Viet Nam from close to the highest point in Bach Ma NP in forest with characteristics approaching montane evergreen forest, but still with an ever-wet climate (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016). One record in Lao PDR comes from the western portion of Xe Sap NPA where semi-evergreen and lower montane forests (following Rundel 1999) predominate (Lamxay 2013); however, intensive and extensive camera-trapping showed that the species is very localised and/or very rare in western Xe Sap NPA. The localised presence of Licuala and Lanonia palm species indicates small patches of ‘ever-wet’ habitat in this area (Timmins 2013) and the lower montane forest areas with a considerable Dalat Pine Pinus dalatensis component (Timmins 2013) are another clear indication that these lower montane forests have reduced dry seasons compared with most such forests in Lao PDR.

Although Annamite Striped Rabbit has potentially a low detectability by camera-trapping as conventionally practised in Indochina, it appears to have been detected by all camera-trapping efforts of more than a few thousand camera-trap-nights in wet evergreen forest (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2018). In stark contrast, it has never been camera-trapped by surveys of similar effort in areas of indisputable semi-evergreen and lower montane forest (following Rundel 1999) in Lao PDR. Particularly telling in this regard are the absence of detections from Nam Et – Phou Louey NPA, Nam Kading NPA, the Nam Ngiap catchment, the Nam Xang – Nam Chouan area, Phou Sithon ESCA, large regions of Nakai – Nam Theun NPA, and much of western Xe Sap NPA: these are all areas with varying degrees of Annamite faunal affinity. In Nakai – Nam Theun NPA the few detections were all in sites where, as with Xe Sap NPA, other indications suggest localised occurrence of wet evergreen forest (or forest strongly transitional with it). Potentially, many Lao populations function as sink populations, because most if not all wet evergreen forest in Lao PDR is likely to be to some extent ‘transitional’ with ‘drier’ semi-evergreen and lower montane forests, and thus is presumably suboptimal for this rabbit.

Camera-trapping from the Hue SNR in central Viet Nam suggests that the species survives in secondary and heavily degraded forest (M. Le pers. comm. 2016).

There is one report of Annamite Striped Rabbit occurrence far from wet evergreen forest, in western Khammouan province, Lao PDR. This was based upon the presentation of a Nesolagus timminsi image to local villagers and a positive response from the villagers that the animal was present in their area (Orlov et al. 2008, A.V. Abramov pers. comm. 2018). However, other independent evidence (R. J. Timmins pers. comm. 2018) indicates that identification of animal images (including mammals as distinctive as Tiger Panthera tigris and Saola) by local villagers is often not reliable. The area reported is a mosaic of karst and rural agriculture, far from wet evergreen forest. Occurrence in this area would, if confirmed, represent a substantial increase in the species’s known range, and would require a comprehensive rethink of biogeographic patterns of occurrence of not only this species, but other Annamite associates as well. On this survey, A. Abramov (pers. comm. 2018) reported also that they found small leporid tracks, and that villagers stated that the animal with which they identified the Annamite Striped Rabbit image was common in the area and an at least occasional pest of rice fields. Factors contesting occurrence in this region are the lack of any evidence of Annamite Striped Rabbit in western Lao PDR despite extensive camera-trapping and the absence of trade records of it in the several fresh wildlife meat markets around Khammouan's western karst: Kha-nyou Laonastes aenigmamus and several other small mammal species of karst are found in these markets quite frequently (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2018). There is no confirmation from anywhere in its range of Annamite Striped Rabbit occurrence in any habitat remote from wet evergreen forest.

Annamite Striped Rabbit appears to be strictly nocturnal: camera-trap records from seven protected areas in the central Annamites (Bach Ma NP, the Hue and Quang Nam SNRs, Phong Dien NR, Khe Nuoc Trong proposed NR, Bac Huong Hoa NR and Xe Sap NPA) were exclusively at night (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016, M. Le pers. comm. 2016, Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2017). It appears to be solitary: the aforementioned systematic camera-trapping in Bach Ma NP, the Hue and Quang Nam SNRs, and Xe Sap NPA showed predominantly lone individuals, with only two exceptions, both of duos (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016, M. Le pers. comm. 2016). Almost nothing is known about reproduction. A duo of kittens, estimated to be approximately one week old, was found in a shallow burrow in Phou Chomvoy Provincial Protected Area, Bolikhamxai province, Lao PDR, during the month of January (O. Vongsa pers. comm. 2015). A second duo of kittens, estimated to be 10–12 weeks of age, were found in Pu Mat NP in the month of May (Abramov et al. 2016).
threats:
Annamite Striped Rabbit is threatened by poaching, with widespread snaring probably the most damaging form, although the species is also caught opportunistically by hunters, sometimes with the aid of dogs. Snaring operations range from the setting of a few snares to supply the camps of forest users not targeting ground-dwelling large mammals, to well-organised gangs focused on supplying such mammals to the national and international trade in wildlife meat and purportedly medicinal products. Indiscriminate wire snares have reduced populations severely of almost all ground-dwelling mammal species of rabbit-size or larger in the Annamites, and while Annamite Striped Rabbit may be slightly buffered from the effects of snaring operations by its small size and presumed small home range, there is both direct and indirect evidence that industrial-level snaring has reduced greatly its population. In Viet Nam, Timmins et al. (1999) mentioned a snared individual from just north of Phong Nha Ke Bang NP; a snared individual was found in Ha Tinh province (Dang et al. 2001); a skeleton was found in a snare by Timmins and Trinh (1999); remains were found in a snare in the same area of Ha Tinh (N. Furey pers. comm. 2002); and one was found in a brush-fence-style snare line in the Hue SNR (A. Tilker pers. comm. 2016). In Lao PDR, one was found dead in a wire snare close to eastern Xe Sap NPA (K. Thongasmouth pers. comm. 2013). At least four animals, all presumed to have been snared, were seen in the local market at Ban Lak-20 (= Ban Lak Xao) in the 1990s (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2018). The numbers observed in snares or otherwise in trade gives no suggestion, relative to the frequency with which other sympatric species have similarly been observed, that snaring pressure is any less significant a threat to rabbits than it is to any other species of similar or larger size. 

The scarcity of records since about 2010 in many localities within the species’s range offers the most compelling evidence of snaring-driven declines. For example, in Bach Ma NP, where both past and current snaring levels have reached staggering magnitudes, Annamite Striped Rabbit appears as of 2018, on the basis of extensive camera-trapping, to be rare (see 'Population'). Although without pre-exploitation baselines it is not possible to prove declines in any particular area, the ecological conditions in Bach Ma NP resemble those in the Hue and Quang Nam SNRs (adjacent to Bach Ma NP), where Annamite Striped Rabbit densities are higher. It is thus reasonable to assume that without intensive hunting pressure, Annamite Striped Rabbit would be much more common in Bach Ma NP than at present, and that its rarity there is a consequence of hunting. Similar patterns of decline are evident at other localities in Viet Nam, including the Ke Go – Khe Net Lowlands: industrial-level snaring is likely to have caused the decline in this species there, as well as in a number of other ground-dwelling species. Although snaring numbers recorded by Willcox et al. (2015) are relatively low (fewer than 1,500 snares), this result came from a relatively small area of forest and during only approximately three months’ survey, indicating a high overall snaring intensity (D.H.A. Willcox pers. comm. 2018). Most wildlife was recorded at the very tops of the hills in the protected area, away from the main snare lines (D.H.A. Willcox pers. comm. 2018). Although information does not span the relevant period, the highest intensity of snaring may have ceased well before the 2010 surveys, given that large numbers of abandoned snares were not found. 

Mortality from hunting dogs occurs in some areas. Local reports from hunters operating near the Quang Nam SNR in central Viet Nam suggest that while hunters do not target Annamite Striped Rabbit with dogs, it is captured opportunistically while hunters walk the streams at night, and that such events may not be uncommon (A. Tilker pers. comm. 2016). Hunters report that when the species is illuminated by lamp-light it freezes, allowing the hunter to shoot the rabbit or the dogs to attack and kill it. Two separate encounters with two separate individuals in the same area of Quang Nam SNR, in which both animals were captured by hand (and then released unharmed), provide evidence for this behaviour (S. Woodfin pers. comm. 2015; A. Tilker pers. comm. 2015). Villagers from Ban Kalo, in Xekong province, Lao PDR, reported a similar opportunistic hunting of Annamite Striped Rabbit using local hunting dogs (A. Tilker pers. comm. 2014). While there is no evidence for a specific market demand for Annamite Striped Rabbit, and while it does not command the high prices of some species targeted for the wildlife trade such as pangolins Manis or some turtles, it is plausible that its meat can sometimes fetch a higher-than-average price because of novelty.

Habitat degradation, loss and fragmentation are major threats only insomuch as they increase accessibility to hunters. Viet Nam’s aggressive road building policy, particularly in border regions, has in recent years increased accessibility to previously little-disturbed habitat for farmers and timber harvesters (semi-commercial and commercial logging operations), as well as for mammal poachers. Dams, which so far have had minimal impact, look set to increase in the future; they not only reduce habitat but also increase accessibility to commercial hunters and harvesters of other forest products, who take wildlife meat opportunistically whilst pursuing other activities. Similarly, the expansion of the road network in many border areas of Lao PDR (e.g., Salavan and Xekong provinces) will improve access into areas of Annamite Striped Rabbit range and, in the absence of functioning law enforcement, increase levels of snaring of mammals potentially to intensities similar to much of the species' Viet Namese range. Mining for gold, gems and other minerals seems to be on the rise, which results in habitat destruction and increased hunting levels.
population:
Although population size and density have not been established anywhere in its range, Annamite Striped Rabbit appears to be noticeably less abundant in heavily hunted areas than in areas perceived on the basis of other evidence to have had lower hunting intensity. Observations and estimates of the intensity of hunting pressure across the species' known and presumed distribution in both range states indicates that at a landscape level this pressure is extremely high, with episodic deployment of snares in the region of dozens to hundreds of snares per km² over periods of years within almost every km² of suitable habitat in these landscapes. Although clear quantification of population size or decline rates is not possible, subjective assessment of available evidence, from camera-trapping of this species and trends in conservation status of other species in the same areas, suggests that substantial range-wide declines are very likely to have occurred. The clearest and most compelling information on the population trend of Annamite Striped Rabbit comes from a camera-trapping project in central Viet Nam. Because camera-trapping as conventionally practised in Indochina is often targeted at animals much larger than in Annamite Striped Rabbit, and for a variety of objectives, there is wide variation in its ability to detect this rabbit reliably. During this specific camera-trapping project in central Viet Nam the cameras were set consistently low enough to record rabbit-sized ground-dwelling mammal species reliably. Systematic such camera-trapping (totalling 6,805 camera-trap-nights) in Bach Ma National Park (= NP) in 2014-2015 at 53 camera-trap stations evenly spaced across the national park detected Annamite Striped Rabbit at only four (7.5%) of the stations, with a total of seven detections (defined as images of the species separated by at least 60 minutes from the previous image of the species at the same station) (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016). Most records came from the more remote and rugged parts of the protected area. More intensive camera-trapping in a core part of the protected area, at finer spatial scale, failed to record the species at 64 stations (8,256 camera-trap-nights), indicating that the species is either extremely rare or extirpated in this part of the protected area (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016).

Camera-trapping in the Hue and Quang Nam Saola Nature Reserves (= SNRs), two contiguous protected areas adjacent to Bach Ma NP, conducted immediately after the Bach Ma NP survey, detected the species more often: it was recorded at 10 (of 39) stations with camera-traps spaced systematically over the protected areas, in a total of 5,933 camera-trap-nights, comprising 47 detections (defined as above). The detection of Annamite Striped Rabbit at 25.6% of the camera-trap stations is far higher than in the landscape-scale camera-trapping in Bach Ma NP, but well below the occupancy of other mammals generally taken to be more resilient to hunting, such as ferret badger(s) Melogale. A further 54 detections (from 14 [of 64] stations) was obtained in an intensive effort in the reserves’ core. This intensive camera-trapping recorded a minimum of 27 individuals, as identified by their unique striping patterns (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016). Unlike Bach Ma NP, the Hue and Quang Nam SNRs have some level of anti-poaching support (although snaring persists at high levels nonetheless), which could indicate that Annamite Striped Rabbit may be able to rebound in the presence of targeted anti-snaring efforts. However, no baseline survey was conducted in this area before anti-poaching activities began, so the population trend remains speculative.

It is likely that the inferred differences in ground-dwelling vertebrate densities (including those of Annamite Striped Rabbit) between Bach Ma NP and the SNRs is caused by Bach Ma NP having been more ‘accessible’ to more hunters for a longer period of time, and so having experienced more sustained hunting pressure than have localities more distant from the high human population density and the high densities of ‘access’-oriented infrastructure that characterise the Viet Namese coastal lowlands. That this is the case largely hinges on the lack of evidence to suggest that Bach Ma NP's habitat quality is lower than that of the SNRs for any of the species apparently less abundant in the former than in the latter (such as Northern Red Muntjac Muntiacus vaginalis, the Roosevelts' Muntjac M. rooseveltorum taxonomic complex, Sambar Rusa unicolor, Crested Argus Rheinardia ocellata, Malayan Porcupine Hystrix brachyura, Masked Palm Civet Paguma larvata, Mainland Serow Capricornis milneedwardsii, and Crab-eating Mongoose Herpestes urva). Apparent patterns of decline from the Bach Ma NP / SNRs forest complex of other species known to be particularly sensitive to snaring, including Crested Argus, suggest that levels of accessibility and/or remoteness may explain distributions of ground-dwelling species, including Annamite Striped Rabbit, in this particular forest block (N. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2018). Ease of access is postulated commonly to affect the distribution and status of many quarry species in South-east Asia (e.g., Harrison et al. 2016), including Annamite species such as Owston’s Civet Chrotogale owstoni, Saola Pseudoryx nghetinhensis and Large-antlered Muntjac Muntiacus vuquangensis (Timmins et al. 2016a,b,c). All available evidence indicates that the current low densities of species such as Crested Argus in areas such as Bach Ma NP can be attributed confidently to substantial snare-induced declines, in many cases probably exceeding 90% over an approximately 20-year period starting in the late 1990s, because reasonably clear data on population status at the beginning of this period exist for these species (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2018).

It appears that Annamite Striped Rabbit occurs at densities broadly similar to those of other species that are considered to be sensitive to snaring and are thought to have declined over a similar time period by rates in excess of 50%. For example, in the combined landscape and intensive camera-trapping in Bach Ma NP mentioned above, representing 117 camera-trap stations and 15,061 camera-trap-nights, Crested Argus was detected at only two stations and Owston’s Civet at, at most, one (the image is insufficiently clear for consensus on its identification); some hunting-sensitive species were not recorded in this effort, including Saola, Sambar and Greater Hog Badger Arctonyx collaris. Species that are believed to be fairly robust to snaring pressure during this survey appeared to be at depressed levels but were nonetheless more frequently photographed than was Annamite Striped Rabbit: Common Palm Civet Paradoxurus hermaphroditus was detected at 48 stations, Asiatic Brush-Tailed Porcupine Atherurus macrourus at 44, and ferret badger(s) at 46 (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016). In sum, Annamite Striped Rabbit seems to be following other hunting-sensitive species into local extirpation in Bach Ma NP.

Given that most of the habitat suitable for the species is in Viet Nam, and that most (perhaps nearly all) of it is probably under levels of hunting pressure not an order of magnitude different from those in Bach Ma NP, it is likely that Annamite Striped Rabbit densities are depressed to broadly similar levels across most of the species’s range. While this is largely a subjective extrapolation by those who have spent years surveying in the species's range, some other recent camera-trapping surveys provide support for the conclusion that the species occurs at low densities in core parts of its distribution (but see the caveat above about the risk of some styles of camera-trapping under-detecting the species). Patterns of hunting pressure and overall defaunation similar to those in Bach Ma NP were found in the Ke Go – Khe Net Lowlands by small carnivore-targeted surveys conducted in 2007, 2008 and 2010. In total, 1,171 camera-trap-nights (with cameras set at heights above ground suitable for detecting the rabbit) and 101 hours of spotlighting did not record Annamite Striped Rabbit. Furthermore, this work failed to record other species believed generally to be sensitive to snaring (Owston’s Civet, Sambar, Greater Hog Badger, Crested Argus), but did record species presumed to be more resilient to hunting, such as Common Palm Civet and Asiatic Brush-tailed Porcupine (Willcox et al. 2015). Targeted camera-trapping in Pu Mat NP in 2015, focused on two interior parts of the protected area, and representing 20 camera-trap stations and approximately 2,500 camera-trap-nights, yielded similar results: no Annamite Striped Rabbit was recorded (Tuan Vo pers. comm. 2017). A sighting of a female Annamite Striped Rabbit with young in 2017 shows that the species persists in Pu Mat NP (Abramov et al. 2016), but this single sighting does not provide evidence that its densities are not severely depressed in the protected area. A camera-trap survey in Ba Na – Nui Chua Nature Reserve (= NR) during 2016–2017, in which 23 camera-trap stations operated for more than one year, in an area adjacent to Bach Ma NP (and within the species’s historical distribution although potentially suboptimal habitat), also failed to record it, and likewise documented low encounter rates for mammals and galliform birds considered to be sensitive to snaring, with Owston’s Civet and Crested Argus recorded at only a single camera-trap station each, and no records of Greater Hog Badger (Hoang Quoc Huy pers. comm. 2018). Not surprisingly, the mammal community in Ba Na – Nui Chua NR appears to have undergone levels of defaunation similar to those at Bach Ma NP and the Ke Go – Khe Net Lowlands (Hoang Quoc Huy pers. comm. 2018).

Surveys in Bac Huong Hoa NR in 2015 and 2016, totalling 134 stations and 5,294 camera-trap-nights, recorded the species at seven (5.22% of) camera-trap stations (Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2017). Surveys in Phong Dien NR in 2016, totalling 84 stations and 4,181 camera-trap-nights, recorded the species at three (3.57% of) stations (Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2017).  Surveys in Khe Nuoc Trong proposed NR from 2012 to 2017, totalling 1,018 independent stations and 33,500 camera-trap-nights, recorded the species at 54 (5.22% of) stations (Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2017). The proportion of stations at which the species was recorded by all three surveys is broadly similar to the results from Bach Ma NP.

In Lao PDR, the species was camera-trapped only twice (at different stations; in 2007) in Nakai – Nam Theun National Protected Area (= NPA) during surveys from 2006 to 2011 covering four survey blocks, which comprised at least some suitable habitats for the species, with a total of 11,126 camera-trap-nights and 201 camera-trap stations (Johnson and Johnston 2007, Nam Theun 2 Watershed Management and Protection Authority pers. comm. 2011). Both stations were within 5 km of the international border. Interpretation of this result is confounded by several factors, notably that most of the NPA is probably unsuitable in forest-type for the species and has therefore never supported a sizeable population of it. Thus, even though intensive snaring had not yet affected much of the NPA by 2006–2011, there was no possibility of recording a high encounter rate with the species. Since 2011, no relevant camera-trapping has taken place to provide up-to-date information on conservation status of ground-dwelling animal populations in the parts of the NPA within which Annamite Striped Rabbit was recorded previously. However, since these two records in 2007, the trade-driven snaring pressure, especially within 5–10 km of the Viet Namese border (where lies most of the habitat suitable for the species in the NPA) has intensified. This suggests that, were surveys to be repeated, they would find severe declines among the more hunting-sensitive ground-dwelling species there (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2016, C.N.Z. Coudrat pers. comm. 2018). Populations of Annamite Striped Rabbit in these areas are, therefore, likely to have declined, possibly to local extinction.

Surveys in the northern and central Annamites during 2012–2017 that focused on assessing hunting pressure (by direct observation of hunting signs, and determining the local status of hunting-sensitive quarry species through direct observation, encounters with animal signs, and opinions of local villagers) support strongly the assumption that the camera-trapping rates expressed above for Viet Nam are a true indication of depressed population density. Excepting surveys in Nakai – Nam Theun NPA, these surveys intentionally entered and assessed the least accessible, remotest, parts of each area (because species status is, often, strongly related to level of human access; Harrison et al. 2016). Although these surveys could not determine directly the current status of Annamite Striped Rabbit, past and current rates of snaring could be inferred along with the status of some of the presumed snaring-sensitive species listed above. In all Viet Namese areas surveyed, including the SNRs, Phong Dien and Bac Huong Hoa NRs and the Bach Ma NP extension, evidence was found that dozens to hundreds of snares per km² had been deployed over periods of multiple years. Encounter rates with ungulate signs in these same areas were well below those in areas with evidence of significantly lower hunting intensity, and calling rates of Crested Argus were vastly lower than the rates heard in ecologically similar forest in the 1990s.  Lao sites however showed considerably more variability in the past and ongoing intensity of snaring. A situation similar to that of Viet Nam was found in the eastern international border area of Nakai – Nam Theun NPA in Lao PDR. In other Lao sites, intensive snaring appeared to be or have been more heterogeneous (for instance, in Xe Sap NPA), although still affecting a majority of the area or in some areas a large minority of the area (generally, the parts closest to the Viet Namese border). Only one landscape, comprising Khoun Xe – Nong Ma Provincial Protected Area (PPA) and Laving Laveun NPA of Central Lao PDR, was found where a substantial proportion of the area showed no signs of current or past intensive snaring pressure. Even within this landscape, signs in border areas evinced snaring intensity not dissimilar to those in surveyed areas of Viet Nam. The areas surveyed included some such as Phou Sithon Endangered Species Conservation Area (ESCA) where, based on habitat and climactic factors, Annamite Striped Rabbit is almost certainly absent, and others such as Xe Sap NPA where occurrence is likely to be highly localised. Overall, given the likely distribution of suitable habitat for Annamite Striped Rabbit, only the Khoun Xe – Nong Ma PPA and Laving Laveun NPA landscape had a sizeable area of suitable habitat with relatively low hunting intensity at this time.

Intensive snaring in the Annamites appears to have begun in the 1990s, when Saola, the Annamite large mammal species now closest to global extinction (Timmins et al. 2016c), was apparently still relatively frequently caught. Since then, surveys often find evidence of intensive snaring; concerns of its severity were already raised before 2000 (e.g. Timmins et al. 1999). However, snaring has not affected all areas simultaneously in similar ways. Instead, intensive snaring appears to have progressed wave-like through the forests of the Annamites, with the progression of the wave, albeit in a somewhat stochastic fashion, most likely related to factors such as access and initial resource abundance. Although there have been no studies of the dynamics, observations suggest that usually at the forefront of the wave (defined as initial entry of poachers to previously unsnared forest areas) snares are deployed intensively, up to thousands per km². Snaring at this density is likely to lead to rapid, extensive declines in all mammal species rabbit-sized and larger, and thus after a few years (perhaps shorter), with the ground-dwelling large mammal community probably typically depleted by more than 80% at a locality, poachers move on. The form of and damage from the next phase probably depends on the relative ease of access and the quantities of other valuable forest resources remaining in the area. In accessible areas (for example, those reachable in a single day’s travel from the nearest human habitation, such as all of Bach Ma NP), snaring probably continues at a sustained and significant level (in the order of dozens of snare-nights per km² per month) because of the low resource cost for snaring in the context of the abundance of other ‘marketable’ forest resources remaining. In areas that take greater effort to enter, for example, those more than a day’s travel away, the situation is probably more complex, although at least periodic episodes of snaring are likely to take place in association with directed poaching of high-value species. However, these remote areas may also remain snaring-free for a considerable time after the initial wave. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, encountering the forefront of this wave was commonplace during Annamite surveys, at which time large areas had not yet experienced intensive snaring at all. But during the 2012–2017 surveys outlined above, the front of the wave was found only in Lao areas, notably in Xe Sap NPA and Khoun Xe – Nong Ma PPA. In all Viet Namese areas the most intensive snaring had clearly passed, probably at least 5–10 years previously. Although continued snaring was found in all Viet Namese areas surveyed during this time, the levels were in most cases considerably less than those which typify the initial forefront of the wave, supporting the conclusion that in accessible forest areas relatively low intensity but widespread snaring occurs, whilst relatively remote areas receive generally more intensive but localised effort. In some cases, notably in Phong Dien NR and even more so the eastern border areas of Nakai – Nam Theun NPA, evidence of recent snaring was limited, though mammal densities appeared to be severely depressed.

Considering observations of snaring from the late 1990s onwards, as of 2018 the core area of Khoun Xe – Nong Ma PPA is almost certainly by far the largest area of Annamite Striped Rabbit range remaining that has yet to experience intensive snaring. Overall, probably more than 95% of the species’s entire range has already experienced high to very high levels of snaring pressure. Given the still increasing demand for wildlife in the thriving illegal trade, and the very small percentage of the species’s range in Lao PDR that had not by 2018 experienced a significantly lower snaring pressure, and therefore is likely to retain healthier populations, Khoun Xe – Nong Ma PPA will almost certainly experience industrial snaring within the next five years unless there are unprecedented enforcement interventions.

Intensive snaring has been ongoing in Annamite Striped Rabbit range for a little over 20 years, yet the Red List Criterion A assessment window is only for ten years, meaning that it is important to consider the portion of the decline that has occurred during 2008–2018. Although there is no baseline for the species's abundance at the start of intensive snaring, the likely progression and magnitude of decline over the quarter-century to 2018 can be proposed. Subjective assessments from wildlife surveyors active in the Annamite forests before industrial snaring indicate that local populations of all ground-dwelling species of mammals of rabbit-size and larger may be reduced initially by close to an order of magnitude (including species often considered ‘hunting-resilient’ such as palm civets and ferret badgers). After this, interpretation is more problematic, in part because some small patches seem to escape the ‘initial crest’ of the snaring wave. By 2008, the start of the time period relevant for assessing Annamite Striped Rabbit under Criterion A, intensive snaring had already probably affected around half, perhaps more, of the species's range, based on field observation up to that period (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2018).  Since 2008, such snaring has affected about 90%, perhaps more, of the range that as of 2008 had not been snared thus (that is, about 45% of the original range). Thus, as of 2018, no more than 5% of the species's original range has never been intensively snared. Assuming that initial Annamite Striped Rabbit population densities are reduced by well over half following landscape-scale intensive snaring, by 2008 populations had already declined by well over 50% in at least half of the species’s range. At this time, the bulk of the population therefore remained in areas not yet intensively snared. Under the foregoing presumptions, from 2008 the small proportion of the global population in the areas already heavily affected has by 2018 presumably declined at a reduced rate (perhaps below 50%), whilst the majority of the unaffected populations has undergone a substantial decline (of more than 50%). It is likely that a small fraction (5% or lower of the total population) did not experience any decline. An average, weighting population trend by the proportion of the global population in each category in 2008, results in a decline of 50% or more for the entire population for the ten years to 2018.

These decline rates seem plausible given the evidence presented above, despite some uncertainty of the relative severity of decline rates during the initial wave relative to ongoing rates thereafter. Areas such as Bach Ma NP, Phong Dien NR, and the Ke Go – Khe Net Lowlands, with good evidence of intensive snaring before 2008, would now have Annamite Striped Rabbit populations substantially below 25% of their early 1990s levels. This inference fits with the general camera-trapping findings given above. The scenario also fits the information from the SNRs where, evidently, intensive snaring generally occurred later (some before, some after 2008). It does not contradict the general conclusion that the recent protection levels in the SNRs might have reduced decline rates substantially or even have lead to minor recovery there, given the strong evidence that substantial snaring activity had already swept through the SNRs before significant anti-poaching enforcement occurred there.

Taken together, available evidence incorporating information from other similar-size ground-dwelling mammal species indicates that the total global population of Annamite Striped Rabbit has declined by more than 50%, plausibly up to 65% over the 10 years to 2018. The rate of decline that will be experienced in the future, now that about 95% of the species' global range has already undergone intensive snaring, depends largely upon the relative difference (if any) between the rates of decline during the first wave relative to the ongoing decline thereafter. Based on slender quantification (such as the numbers of snared Annamite Striped Rabbits found in the 1990s versus those found since 2008; see below), the current status in areas such as Phong Dien NR and Bach Ma NP may reflect substantial initial declines (perhaps of about 75%, maybe higher) but lower decreases since then (perhaps 30% or even lower, and perhaps even localised recovery). It is therefore possible that in the ten years to 2028 declines would not meet the 50% threshold. However, taking a precautionary viewpoint, particularly given the increasing trend in regional natural resource exploitation in general, and industrial snaring in particular, a further 50% decline is quite plausible in the future.
range: Annamite Striped Rabbit occurs at low and medium altitudes in the northern and central Annamite Mountains along the Viet Nam and Lao PDR border. In Viet Nam, it is believed to occur in six provinces (listed from north to south): Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Thua Thien Hue and Quang Nam. In Lao PDR it is believed to occur also in six provinces (from north to south): Xiangkhouang (unconfirmed), Bolikhamxai, Khammouan, Savannakhet, Salavan and Xekong. There are no records from the southern parts of the central Annamites or from the southern Annamites but these regions are not obviously ecologically unsuitable. The westward extent of occurrence in Lao PDR appears to be tied closely to localised climactic factors, with all indications suggesting that the species is strongly associated with wet evergreen forest. Fitting this, it has been confirmed in the Lao PDR only in areas close to the border with Viet Nam: a pattern shown by various other wet evergreen forest indicator species. The Annamite ridge forms most of the international border between the two countries and places most of Lao PDR in the rain-shadow of moisture-laden air masses from Viet Nam in the Lao dry season. The vast majority of habitat suitable for Annamite Striped Rabbit is therefore in Viet Nam. Most records come from below 1,000 m and the species has been recorded nearly down to sea level (50 m asl; Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2018), although few low-altitude areas retain otherwise suitable habitat. The highest record traced was at 1,300 m asl (A. Tilker, A. Nguyen The Truong and A. Wilting pers. comm. 2016).
useTrade: Although there is no evidence of a targeted trade for the species, it is certainly hunted as part of the thriving wildlife trade that occurs across its known range. Given the paucity of information suggesting that the species has a high value for wildlife trade, it is likely that when caught, it often ends up in the local fresh wildlife meat markets, or is used for primary consumption. In fact, the first evidence of Nesolagus in mainland South-east Asia came from a subsistence market in rural Lao PDR (Surridge et al. 1999).
conservationActions:
Although habitat loss and degradation have undoubtedly been factors in Annamite Striped Rabbit population declines from historical levels, the primary threat to the species is the intensive snaring that occurs across Annamite forests, and which is especially high in northern and central Viet Nam (which areas comprise most of the species's known range). It is difficult to convey the intensity of snaring in the Annamites: in many protected areas, hundreds of snares can be collected in a single day’s walk, and elaborate brush-fence-style snare lines can reach several kilometres in length (Gray et al. 2017, 2018). It is therefore no surprise that, as with other rare and threatened ground-dwelling Annamite endemic mammal species, the highest priority for Annamite Striped Rabbit is effective law enforcement to curtail the industrial-level snaring that occurs across the region, combined with efforts to reduce the demand for wildlife meat and products sold as medicines (the ultimate driver of snaring throughout the Annamites) amongst the increasing middle classes in Viet Nam, Lao PDR and further afield (whether or not this rabbit is ever traded further afield does not affect the merit of this recommendation, as it is simply one species among a large general catch, driven by market demand in not just Lao PDR and Viet Nam). The challenges to enacting effective protected area-based law enforcement are substantial: neither Viet Nam nor Lao PDR has a historical model upon which to base effective protected area management, and government support remains weak, involving laws and decrees that have, typically, little follow-up action. Protected areas across the species’s range remain little more than paper parks, and if the species is to survive in the wild, this situation must change fundamentally. Some success has been achieved by joint government- and NGO-led snare-removal teams operating in the Hue and Quang Nam SNRs in Viet Nam and in neighbouring Xe Sap NPA in Lao PDR, operating under the direction of the WWF ‘Carbon and Biodiversity’ (CarBi) project. Over a five-year period, these patrols have removed more than 75,000 snares from the SNRs and the eastern section of Xe Sap NPA (Gray et al. 2018). Notable as these achievements are, the level of snaring in all three protected areas remains extremely high, with snaring intensity plausibly reaching thousands of snare-nights per square kilometre per year (A. Tilker pers. comm. 2017). Therefore, although this joint management model provides some hope for future protection for Annamite Striped Rabbit from intensive snaring in at least one forest block, considerable increase in effectiveness is needed before any part of this forest complex could be considered safe for the species (or any other ground-dwelling Annamite endemic mammal). Most other protected areas known or likely to hold the species are probably at least as exploited and as of 2018 receive minimal law enforcement effort or snare removal.

Because of the challenges that remain in the effective management of  protected area, it is vital that conservation stakeholders consider within the next few years the establishment a captive ‘insurance’ population of this species. Currently it is not held in captivity. Although it is true that the urgency to establish an insurance population of Annamite Striped Rabbit is lower than for some other Annamite endemic mammals, notably Saola Pseudoryx nghetinhensis, it would be prudent to secure an ex situ population of Annamite Striped Rabbit in the near future: the general snaring-driven declines are unlikely to slow in coming years. Establishing a captive population for Annamite Striped Rabbit should be less difficult than for the much larger and rarer Saola: unlike Saola, the rabbit still exists in detectable densities within several forest blocks in both Viet Nam and Lao PDR, and it should be much easier to capture, in part because of its habitat of becoming immobile when encountered with a headlamp at night. Indeed, as long as proper international expertise to oversee the care of captured individuals can be secured, there seems little downside in establishing an insurance population sooner rather than later.

rationale: Owston's Civet is listed as Endangered A2bcd, A3bcd, A4cd because of an ongoing population decline, inferred to exceed 50% over the last three generations (taken as 15 years) and suspected to continue for the next three. This is inferred from over-exploitation, with habitat fragmentation exacerbating the speed at which the species is being extirpated. Hunting is a severe threat because the species is primarily ground-dwelling and so is exposed to the very high levels of snaring and other forms of ground-level trapping throughout its range. This assessment is made without any direct quantification of decline rate. Two largely sympatric ungulates of broadly similar generation lengths, Saola Pseudoryx nghetinhensis and Large-antlered Muntjac Muntiacus vuquangensis, are proposed as Critically Endangered under the same criteria for the same reasons. Owston's Civet has always been and remains more widespread than them, and unlike them there is still evidence of several high-density Owston's Civet populations. While this does not necessarily mean the civet's overall population decline rate is lower, the lower category for Owston's Civet is assigned based on its wider occurrence in montane forest (in which this civet is known to live, in some areas commonly, and up to 2,600 m) and karst (which is predicted to hold viable populations). These habitats, which contain some areas of very rugged and/or highland terrain into which industrial snaring has not yet widely spread, are apparently not occupied by the two ungulates. If market forces drive intensive snaring also into these habitats, then Critically Endangered would be the appropriate category for future decline rates of Owston's Civet given its apparent rapid extirpation across some heavily snared parts of Viet Nam.
habitat:
Owston’s Civet occurs in a variety of habitats, all within evergreen biomes, linked by the common feature of a non-harsh dry season. It is, or was, much more widely spread in Viet Nam than in Lao PDR, reflecting the much larger area of Viet Nam with significant humidity in the driest months (i.e., lacking a harsh dry season). The pattern of locality records in Lao PDR where the species is evidently naturally localised quite clearly shows that the species has a narrow habitat usage. Areas with a non-harsh dry season in Lao PDR are restricted (Timmins and Trinh 2001). The areas providing high encounter rates of Owston's Civet in Lao PDR are adjacent to low sections of the Annamite spine (the north-south mountain range forming much of the international border between Lao PDR and Viet Nam) that allow moisture-bearing winds from Viet Nam during Lao PDR's dry season, which in the rest of the country is harsh at lower and mid altitudes (Timmins and Trinh 2001, Duckworth et al. 2010, Sivilay et al. 2011, Coudrat et al. 2014). Many other evergreen forest survey areas across the country lack records, despite the use therein of methods suitable to find the species, at adequate intensities, and the finding of multiple hunting-sensitive ground-dwelling mammals, It is essentially absent from the predominant evergreen forest types of Lao PDR, lowland, mid-elevation and lower montane semi-evergreen (dry evergreen) and lower montane forests. This is based on spotlighting in several survey areas supporting these forest types in the early - mid 1990s (Duckworth 1997) and on camera-trapping in the 21st century in Phou Sithon, Nakai-Nam Theun National Biodiversity Conservation Area (NBCA), Laving-Laveun NBCA, Nam Kading NBCA, Phou Chomvoy Provincial Protected Area and Xe Sap NBCA (Duckworth et al. 2010, Coudrat et al. 2014, Gray et al. 2014b, R. J. Timmins pers. comm. 2014); the hunting intensity in all of these at the time of camera-trapping was equivalent to Pu Mat before (sometimes well before) 1998, about when the species was still readily detected by camera-traps. It is evidently locally present in Lao PDR below 1,000 m where wet evergreen forest occurs, but the absence of records from Laving-Laveun NBCA, which holds various other wet evergreen forest species, suggests that Owston's Civet is particularly sensitive to climatic conditions. It also occurs in montane evergreen forest (over 1,000 m), but is probably equally restricted by climatic conditions in its geographic and altitudinal range. Montane areas with wet climates, such as various high peaks in eastern parts of Lao PDR, appear to support the species over a relatively wide range (e.g., Xe Sap NBCA; Gray et al. 2014b), whilst peaks further west (greater rain-shadowing during the winter) appear to support more localised populations (e.g. Nam Et-Phou Louey NBCA; Johnson et al. 2009). Wet evergreen forest is, or was, far more widespread in Viet Nam than in Lao PDR, but it is not universal. The strong evidence from Lao PDR for climatic sensitivity of Owston's Civet suggests that some Viet Namese evergreen forests will hold the species sparsely or not at all (those in a rain-shadow). 

In the Annamite wet evergreen forest of Lao PDR, Owston's Civet has been recorded as high as suitable survey has occurred (1,500 m; Gray et al. 2014b). The few records from Lao PDR's northern highlands, mostly imprecisely located (barring that in Johnson et al. 2009), are likely to come from higher altitudes where the colder temperatures ameliorate the low dry-season rainfall. Thus, in Lao PDR Owston's Civet is likely to occur mostly in hill and montane altitudes, although there are credible reports from as low as 550 m (Gray et al. 2014b), whereas in Viet Nam the species has a wide altitudinal range, right down to the plains and up to 2,600 m (Van Ban district, Lao Kay province, in 2002; S. Swan pers. comm. 2014). Recent camera-trap records at Mu Cang Chai and Muong La, in the northern highlands of Viet Nam, come from altitudes of 1,722-2,444 m a.s.l.; there was very little survey effort below 1,700 m (B.M. Rawson pers, comm. 2014).

Captive animals in both Viet Nam and the U.K. relish earthworms (J. Meek pers. comm. 2014, D.H.A. Willcox pers. comm. 2014) and the species's skull and dentition suggest an invertebrate diet (Thomas 1927). An earthworm-dominated diet would explain the tight linkage with year-round humidity, given that in the parts of Lao PDR with a harsh dry season earthworms are not accessible during that season. This remains purely speculative, especially given that the component of Owston's Civet range south of the northern highlands resembles that of various other species unlikely to depend directly on access to earthworms, e.g. Annamite Striped Rabbit Nesolagus timminsi and Saola Pseudoryx nghetinhensis.

Suitable forests, in Viet Nam at least, include some on limestone and some dominated by bamboo (Roberton 2007). There are indications from Lao PDR of occurrence in degraded and edge habitat such as banana gardens (King 2002), but these remain to be confirmed. The lack of records from deciduous forest surely reflects the genuine pattern of occurrence.

Owston's Civet has not been studied in the field, but camera-trapping indicates that it is nocturnal, largely solitary and presumably largely active at ground level (e.g., Coudrat et al. 2014), although there is at least one record of a wild animal 3 m up a tree (Dang and Le 2010). The species climbs well in captivity (D.H.A. Willcox pers. comm. 2014).
threats:
Lao PDR and Viet Nam, the two countries holding most of the geographic range of Owston's Civet, have among the highest levels of non-specific mammal hunting in the world. For many decades hunting with projectiles, dogs, and traps fabricated from local plant materials has been very high, for largely local use. From the late 1980s, rising throughout the 1990s, 2000s and into the 2010s, rapidly increasing affluence of Chinese and Viet Namese consumers and, to a lesser extent, those in Lao PDR has fuelled an explosive rise in urban demand for wildlife meat, including civets (e.g., Bell et al. 2004). In Viet Nam “the free market economy has resulted in feverish periods of trade in wild species nationwide, with negative impacts on biodiversity” (Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 2004). In Lao PDR, the same situation has developed, largely for export rather than in-country consumption. This demand has resulted in levels of snaring probably unprecedented anywhere in the world, using durable materials (metal) linked by brushwood drift-fences. These are evidently extremely efficient in extirpating mobile ground-dwelling mammals of civet size (e.g., Coudrat et al. 2014); some areas of little-degraded forest now support negligible densities of ground-dwelling mammals of this size class and above (Willcox et al. 2014).

Although such trade-driven off-take of large mammals from protected areas and such wildlife trade is unambiguously illegal in both Lao PDR and Viet Nam, enforcement is uneven and the large profits to be made hamper effective resolution of the problem. In parts of Lao PDR, trade prices for wild meat are so high and wild stocks so depleted that severe dietary problems are evident among rural hill people (i.e., those without access rights to productive fisheries) (Krahn and Johnson 2007). There is no reason to expect these hunting levels to decline until the wildlife species affected have been hunted out; larger species such as big cats Panthera, wild cattle Bos and Sambar Rusa unicolor are already widely extirpated in Viet Nam and Lao PDR (R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2014), yet hunting continues. Some Viet Namese areas camera-trapped and discussed by Willcox et al. (2014) were almost bereft of any ground-dwelling mammals or birds bigger than rats. This is the plausible end-point for most areas holding Owston's Civet.

By contrast, Owston's Civet seems to be fairly resilient to long-standing hunting methods and intensities, judging by the numbers that were and still are camera-trapped in in Viet Nam's northern highlands (Swan and O'Reilly 2004, S. Swan pers. comm. 2004, B.M. Rawson pers. comm. 2014). In contrast to Owston's Civet, many other hunting-sensitive species in these areas were or are already extirpated or reduced to numbers so low as to evade detection. This area has no or negligible trade-driven operation of metal snares in long lines; this lack is typical of Hmong-dominated northern highland areas (J. Tordoff pers. comm. 2014). Most hunting for mammals of civet-size and over in these areas is active, with projectiles and with dogs, rather than by passive trapping; and it is by day (B. Long pers comm. 2014). The nocturnal, solitary, generally inconspicuous habits of Owston's Civet evidently facilitate its survival in such areas; its dens must be in areas not readily found by dogs.

Habitat loss, degradation and fragmentation have affected large areas of Owston’s Civet range (Schreiber et al. 1989), particularly in Viet Nam and increasingly in Lao PDR. Habitat fragmentation magnifies the impact of hunting on populations, particularly when roads are built into areas of, until then, limited accessibility. Vehicle access makes the harvest of a whole host of mid-price marketable materials such as civet meat economically viable where previously the labour investment of carrying heavy loads long distances restrained off-take in those areas to high-value products and what was required for living off the land during the process. An ongoing massive expansion of the road system in Lao PDR, in part related to large infrastructure construction such as dams and mines (e.g., Sivilay et al. 2011, W.G. Robichaud pers. comm. 2014), is likely to bring most of the Lao areas holding Owston's Civet within close-enough range of vehicle access that general wildlife meat extraction is economically feasible. This is already the case for most of the Viet Namese areas.

The exceptions to this grim assessment include karst massifs (into which road building is rarely economically viable), montane areas inhabited by people who disdain snaring, and any protected areas which develop effective enough management regimes before the species is extirpated. While there are Owston's Civet records form karst, densities within such landscapes are unknown, as is the degree to which the species depends upon tall forests there (themselves rather patchy in occurrence in karst landscapes). The extent to which industrial snaring will spread into hill areas already largely depleted of animals larger than civets (by day-time shooting and hunting with dogs), notably large areas of the northern highlands, is unclear; if some such areas do not start to deploy it (for various reasons, such as ongoing remoteness from road networks, or the cultural predispositions of the inhabitants), these areas will also be important havens to Owston's Civet.

The adaptability of Owston's Civet to non-hunted degraded and fragmented areas is unknown, but so long as snaring remains uncontrolled, is moot.
population:
The total population of Owston's Civet will always have been much smaller than that of most other mainland South-east Asian civets because it has such a small geographic range. There is insufficient baseline information to define the precise range and even the general abundance in the era before trade-driven hunting began to accelerate steeply in the 1980s with the increasingly wide deployment of cable-snares in long lines linked by brushwood drift fences. Therefore, its population trend needs to be inferred from trends in habitat and in hunting (types, distributions and intensities), based on a hypothesised geographic and ecological distribution, itself inferred from habitat (from which the known precisely located records come) and distributions of ecologically restricted co-occurring species.

Severe declines probably started in the early 1990s, Around this time, evidence suggests other ground-dwelling, now much-declined, Annamite-centred species such as Saola Pseudoryx nghetinhensis, Large-antlered Muntjac Muntiacus vuquangensis and Edwards’s Pheasant Lophura edwardsii were, by today’s standards, still common in accessible Viet Namese forests. Camera-trapping in the late 1990s in Pu Mat Nature Reserve and in Huong Son district (SFNC 2000, Timmins and Trinh 2001) suggested that the species was still relatively common in mid-elevation forests where hunting pressure was already relatively intense. The number of animals in trade in the 1990s (e.g., at Ban Lak-20 (= Ban Lak Xao) in Lao PDR; received by the Owston’s Civet Project at Cuc Phuong National Park, Viet Nam; and observed in trade near Phong Nha-Ke Bang National Park and as stuffed specimens along route 1, both Viet Nam) all suggest the species was frequent thereabouts, presumably in the mid-elevation forest where the bulk of snaring was then taking place. There is no pointer, when the difficulties of detecting this species by typical pre-camera-trap surveys are accounted for, to suggest that Owston’s Civet was not a common species throughout mid-elevation Vietnamese wet evergreen forest (see 'Habitats and ecology' section), prior to the advent of intensive snaring.

Within its range, it evidently reached, and locally still reaches, high densities within favoured habitat. Bourret (1944) considered it to be the most common civet between the Fansipan mountains and the Black river in northern Viet Nam. Two camera-trapping surveys in Viet Nam around the turn of the century, one in the Hoang Lien mountains in the north-west of the country and the other in Pu Mat Nature Reserve in the northern Annamites found this civet to be among the most commonly photographed small carnivores in these areas (SFNC 2000, S. Swan pers. comm. 2004). Pu Mat NR has not been resurveyed, but this assessment is still appropriate for the highland areas of Mu Cang Chai and Muong La, both in/near the Hoan Lien mountains, in 2013 camera-trapping (B.M. Rawson pers. comm. 2014). The same was found in 2012-2013 in Xe Sap National Protected Area, Lao PDR (Gray et al. 2014b) and during the preceding decade in parts of eastern Nakai-Nam Theun NPA (Coudrat et al. 2014). In some other areas that it has been found, it has been among the least recorded species by camera-trap, e.g. Quang Nam province, Viet Nam (Long and Minh 2006), western Nakai-Nam Theun NPA (Coudrat et al. 2014), and Nam Et-Phou Louey NPA in the northern highlands of Lao PDR (Johnson et al. 2009). The patterns of the other hunting-sensitive species recorded by these surveys suggest that Owston's Civet abundance is highly heterogeneous dependent upon habitat, not that the low encounter rates in these areas are solely a result of overhunting (although this might be responsible in part or whole for the low encounter rate in Quang Nam).

However, hunting is likely to be the explanation for the stark temporal pattern shown by the review of camera-trapping in Viet Nam by Willcox et al. (2014: Table SOM3). Of the five camera-trapping surveys operating in Viet Nam during 1998–2006, all found Owston’s  Civet; the four in 2006–2013 all did not. (Two additional sites surveyed in the latter period, Cat Tien NP and U Minh, also did not find Owston’s Civet but are excluded from the comparison as being outside the species's likely range.) Very recent (late 2013) camera-trapping in Ngoc Linh Nature Reserve (Kon Tum province, Viet Nam) and two northern highland sites, Mu Cang Chai and Muong La, found Owston's Civet to be one of most commonly photographed small carnivores (Nguyen T. pers. comm. 2014, B.M. Rawson pers. comm. 2014). These anomalies within the 2006-2013 time period, not available in time for the Willcox et al. (2014) review, are both in very mountainous areas consequently less economically appealing to market hunters. Higher hunting pressures, notably snaring intensities, typify most of the survey areas included in Willcox et al. (2014: Table SOM3). Excepting the results from Ngoc Linh NR, Mu Cang Chai and Muong La, the lack of Viet Namese records from 2006 onwards suggests a major recent decline in the species in sites across the country with large populations left only in forested steep highland massifs. This suspected decline is corroborated by the failure of over 15,000 camera-trap-nights of effort in wet evergreen forest (see 'Habitats and ecology' section) in the Hue and Quang Nam Saola Reserves, Viet Nam, since August 2012 to find the species (WWF pers. comm. to Gray et al. 2014b). Nor has it been found in another lowland area of wet evergreen forest, Khe Nuoc Truong in Quang Binh province, where extensive camera-trapping recorded many other small carnivore species (Le Trong Trai pers. comm. 2014). For none of these 2006-2013 Viet Nam camera-trap survey areas is there evidence of a pre-intensive-snaring large population of Owston' Civet. However, assessing them based on habitat and other Annamite wet evergreen forest species' status (see 'Habitats and ecology' section; R.J. Timmins [pers. comm. 2014] has surveyed in most of them and studied all on aerial imagery), Khe Nuoc Truong, Hoang Son, and non-limestone forests in the Phong Nha-Ke Bang area, are probably prime Owston’s Civet habitat; Hue and Quang Nam Saola Nature Reserves are very similar to Pu Mat NR; and Ke Go is hard to know, because few other sites are topographically similar, and the topography influences local climate. Even Crested Argus Rheinardia ocellata (among the least hunting-sensitive ground-dwelling wet evergreen forest species) has not been camera-trapped in the Hue and Quang Nam Saola Reserves; they are some of the most heavily hunted large forest blocks that R.J. Timmins (pers. comm. 2014) has ever been to.

A decline of such magnitude was not suspected during the last Red List assessment for this species, for 2008. At that stage, all camera-trap surveys within its range typically found the species, sometimes commonly. The high encounter rates in some areas suggests a high starting population and thus a long time until near extirpation (and the concomitant ability of generalised camera-trapping to note a paucity of records). Another factor weighed for the 2008 listing as Vulnerable was that one of the surveys camera-trapping the species commonly, in Hoang Lien Son of far northern Viet Nam, was amid highly degraded and fragmented forest which had been subjected to high levels of traditional hunting for decades (see Swan and O'Reilly 2004) and thus the species was resilient to hunting pressure. However, it now seems more likely that Owston's Civet differs in sensitivity to different styles of hunting (see 'Threats'). The current overall population trend is thus assessed to be steeply downwards. Probably, the main phase of decline in Viet Nam has already occurred, with most areas holding the species there now having only low numbers with large populations persisting only in the northern highlands and most rugged part of the Annamites, Lao PDR, retaining much larger areas of forest without road incursion and a much lower human population, still retains at least one large population, plausibly several (Gray et al. 2014b), but the national trend in 2015-2030 is likely to replicate that of Viet Nam in 1999-2014.

No information on the present population status in the Chinese part of the range was traced. Indeed, it is not clear that the species is still extant there.
range:
Owston's Civet is known to occur across a wide latitudinal range of both eastern Lao PDR (Sivilay et al. 2011, Coudrat et al. 2014, Gray et al. 2014b) and Viet Nam (Roberton 2007, Dang and Le 2010), and in a small area of southernmost China, possibly only in Hekou, Luchun and Jinping counties of Yunnan province (Wang Ying-xiang 2003) but perhaps also in adjacent Guangxi province (Lau et al. 2010). It has not been found west of the Mekong river (Corbet and Hill 1992) and indeed occurrence in Lao PDR is restricted largely to the easternmost areas that have similarities in climate to Viet Nam. The range may also potentially extend into easternmost Cambodia: two individuals seen in the Phnom Tamao zoo (Phnom Penh) collection of stuffed mounts in the late 1990s were unlikely to have originated outside Cambodia (C.M. Poole pers. comm. to Dang and Le 2010). However, extensive surveys in Cambodia's eastern provinces have not found the species (e.g., Gray et al. 2014a, E.H.B. Pollard pers. comm. 2012). Perhaps the most likely area of Cambodia, eastern Virachey National Park, remains very little camera-trapped. Suitable methodology (camera-trapping and/or spotlighting) has been applied widely enough in the southern half of Lao PDR to be confident the species is entirely or largely restricted to the east in the south and latitudinal centre; capable searches have been less widespread in the northern highlands.

Records come from the range 100-2,600 m, but, particularly west of the Annamites, only a subset of this full range is likely to be occupied in any given area (see 'Habitats and ecology').
useTrade: Owston's Civet is taken for meat and traditional medicine (including its bones, scent gland, and penis) in all of its range countries; there is not suspected to be any targeted hunting of the species, but much hunting in its range is non-selective (e.g. snares) to supply the general wildlife meat market (Sivilay et al. 2011, B. Long pers. comm. 2006, S.I. Roberton pers. comm. 2006).
conservationActions:
Owston's Civet is listed as Endangered on the China Red List and as Vulnerable in the Viet Nam Red Book (MOSTE 2000). It is protected in Yunnan province, but not in Guangxi (GMA Small Carnivore Workshop 2006). In Viet Nam the species is listed in group IIB meaning exploitation is regulated but not prohibited (Decree 32/2006/ND-CP). In Lao PDR, the species is listed in group I (Prohibition category) of the hunting regulations (Prime Minister Decree 81, 2008; Wildlife hunting regulation).

An international breeding programme, coordinated from Viet Nam, has been established with populations in Europe and Viet Nam. However numbers are still too low for long-term viability (J. Meek pers. comm. 2014).

Owston's Civet has been recorded in many protected areas in Viet Nam and several in Lao PDR (Roberton 2007, Sivilay et al. 2011, Coudrat et al. 2014, Gray et al. 2014b) but in none of these is trade-driven snaring yet under effective control. They have, however, somewhat to greatly slowed the expansion of the road system, and thus maintained areas in which it is only marginally economically viable to harvest wildlife meat in bulk; and they have reduced the chance of landscape-level habitat transformation projects such as concession plantations.

rationale: Hose's Civet is listed as Vulnerable because its population is likely to be lower than 10,000 mature individuals, based on an area of occupancy (AOO) estimated as 28,000 km²; the assumption of a very patchy distribution even within this area; an indicative population density of one individual per km² (based on studies of similar-sized, largely ground-dwelling civets such as Malay Civet Viverra tangalunga in Borneo; e.g., Colón 2002) in areas considered highly ‘suitable’ for the species; and the very low detection rates in other areas suggesting overall density to be much below this. It is also estimated that there will be an ongoing population decline of at least 10% over the next three generations (taken as 15 years). This decline is expected because of increased pressure on higher-elevation forests as a result of expansion of logging activities and monoculture plantations to higher elevations, coupled with increase in shifting agriculture and indiscriminate hunting practices using nets and snares as a result of human displacement caused by mega hydro-electric dam projects in the centre of Borneo. The combination of such human-induced activities poses the threat of a highly fragmented landscape through which habitat specialists such as Hose’s Civet may be less able to disperse than at present, leading to increasingly isolated populations. Although there are no figures to support this ongoing decline in population size, it is precautionary to acknowledge that these threats will probably take place within the next 15 years, and so to classify the species as Vulnerable.
habitat: The few records of Hose’s Civet and the paucity of research on the species render its habitat preference and ecology difficult to characterise. The full elevational range of existing records extends from 325 m (Samejima and Semiadi 2012) to 1,700 m a.s.l. (Dinets 2003) though whether this upper limit of 1,700 m is a real guideline occurrence limit or simply an artefact of search effort patterns remains to be ascertained. Current records suggest that a large proportion of the species may occur at elevations above 800 m. However, Samejima and Semiadi (2012) suggest that in some parts of the species’s range, such as the Schwaner Mountains in Central Kalimantan, areas below 450 m may be part of its main habitat.
